head.title: Photonic excess noise and wave localization

article.h1: Photonic excess noise and wave localization

span.span: C. W. J. Beenakker and M. Patra
Instituut-Lorentz, Universiteit Leiden, P.O. Box 9506, 2300 RA Leiden, The Netherlands
Laboratory of Atomic and Solid State Physics, Cornell University, Ithaca NY 14853, USA

div.p: This is a theory for the effect of localization on the super-Poissonian noise of radiation propagating through an absorbing disordered waveguide. Localization suppresses both the mean photon current I¯¯𝐼OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-I ARG:end\bar{I} and the noise power P𝑃italic-PP, but the Fano factor P/I¯𝑃¯𝐼italic-P MULOP:divide OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-I ARG:endP/\bar{I} is found to remain unaffected. For strong absorption the Fano factor has the universal value 1+32⁢f132𝑓NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-f1+\frac{3}{2}f (with f𝑓italic-ff the Bose-Einstein function), regardless of whether the waveguide is long or short compared to the localization length.

The coherent radiation from a laser has Poisson statistics [1, 2]. Its noise power PPoissonsubscript𝑃Poissonitalic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Poisson POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP_{\rm Poisson} equals the mean current I¯¯𝐼OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-I ARG:end\bar{I} (in units of photons per second). Elastic scattering has no effect on the noise, because the radiation remains in a coherent state. The coherent state is degraded by absorption, resulting in an excess noise P-PPoisson>0𝑃subscript𝑃Poisson0italic-P ADDOP:minus italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Poisson POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0P-P_{\rm Poisson}>0 [3]. The Fano factor P/PPoisson𝑃subscript𝑃Poissonitalic-P MULOP:divide italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start Poisson POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP/P_{\rm Poisson} deviates from unity by an amount proportional to the Bose-Einstein function f𝑓italic-ff. It is a small effect (f∼10-2similar-to𝑓superscript102italic-f RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endf\sim 10^{-2} at room temperature for infrared frequencies), but of interest because of its fundamental origin: The excess noise is required to preserve the canonical commutation relations of the electromagnetic field in an absorbing dielectric [4, 5, 6].

The interference of multiply scattered waves may lead to localization [7]. Localization suppresses both the mean current and the fluctuations — on top of the suppression due to absorption. Localization is readily observed in a waveguide geometry [8], where it sets in once the length L𝐿italic-LL of the waveguide becomes longer than the localization length ξ≃N⁢lsimilar-to-or-equals𝜉𝑁𝑙italic-xi RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-N italic-l\xi\simeq Nl (with l𝑙italic-ll the mean free path and N𝑁italic-NN the number of propagating modes). Typically, ξ𝜉italic-xi\xi is much larger than the absorption length ξasubscript𝜉aitalic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi_{\rm a}, so that localization and absorption coexist. The interplay of absorption and localization has been studied previously for the mean current [9, 10, 11, 12]. Here we go beyond these studies to include the current fluctuations.

It is instructive to contrast the super-Poissonian photonic noise with the sub-Poissonian electronic analogue. In the case of electrical conduction through a disordered wire, the (zero-temperature) noise power is smaller than the Poisson value as a result of Fermi-Dirac statistics. The reduction is a factor 1/313NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:31/3 in the absence of localization [13, 14]. The effect of localization is to restore Poisson statistics, so that the Fano factor increases from 1/313NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:31/3 to 1 when L𝐿italic-LL becomes larger than ξ𝜉italic-xi\xi. What we will show in this paper is that the photonic excess noise responds entirely differently to localization: Although localization suppresses P𝑃italic-PP and I¯¯𝐼OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-I ARG:end\bar{I}, the Fano factor remains unaffected, equal to the value 1+32⁢f132𝑓NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end italic-f1+\frac{3}{2}f obtained in the absence of localization [15, 16].
Let us begin our analysis with a more precise formulation of the problem. The noise power

In conclusion, we have demonstrated that localization of radiation in an absorbing disordered waveguide has no effect on the ratio of the excess noise and the mean current. In the limit of a large number of propagating modes, this ratio is self-averaging and takes on the universal value of 3/232NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:23/2 times the Bose-Einstein function. Observation of this photonic analogue of the universal 1/313NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:31/3 reduction of electronic shot noise presents an experimental challenge.
